column1: The asterisk is a symbol used in historical linguistics. J.R.R. Tolkien made use of asterisks in his texts about Elvish languages.

column2: an asterisk immediately before a word indicates that the word is not directly attested
column3: but has been reconstructed on the basis of other linguistic material (see also Wikipedia:comparative method). The asterisk shows that this form of word is hypothetical and historically it could be more or less different.

column1: Asterisks are therefore used mostly in the reconstruction unwritten or prehistorical languages
column2: deduced by comparison between other languages.

column1: For example the Old English word endleofan suggests a Proto-Germanic form was *ainlif. The Proto-Germanic people did not have a writing
column3: and this is indicated with an asterisk.

column4: and belong in a stage of a language before the Tengwar or the Cirth. As such
column5: an asterix prefixed to a word indicates that the form is "hypothetical". As noted by Christopher Tolkien
column6: such a marking means that the form is "deduced to have existed from later
column7: recorded forms". Asterisks are used most usually in Primitive Quendian.

column1: For example Tolkien gives *luktiênê as the ancient form of the name Lúthien.
The purpose of Tolkien using asterisks for his personal writings is not known
column2: and it is possible that he used them as a personal in-joke and to persuade himself that he worked  as a historian; or perhaps in order to keep a personal note that these forms were invented by being based on the "later" forms of the words
column3: and could change in some future revision.

column2: even the asterisked forms of Tolkien are considered "valid" and as canonical as the unasterisked ones.

column1: Students of Tolkiens languages also use asterisks to show that some forms are hypothetical logically deduced from Tolkiens derivation of the languages
column2: although Tolkien himself didnt write that form in any of his published texts.

column1: For example the word *corma is a hypothetical word believed to mean "ring". It is seen only as part of the word cormacolindo meaning "Ring-bearer". The form of the longer word makes it obvious that a word "corma" probably exists in Quenya. But since the word as it is
column2: is never written clearly by Tolkien
column3: it is considered as hypothetical and marked with an asterisk.

column1: Asterisks are also used to show ancient forms of attested words. The Sindarin word hobas from Sundocarmë KHOP points to an Old Sindarin intermediate *khopasse. Tolkien never wrote this word
column2: but the rules of Sindarin etymology makes this form the only possibility; however proper referencing requires an asterisk to make clear that it is not a word given by Tolkien.

column1: Students also sometimes employ a double asterisk ** to indicate a mistaken hypothetical form to clarify an example. A mistaken form would be Primitive Quendian **aladâ instead of the correct galadâ. They both would bring Quenya alda but the former would bring Sindarin **aladh instead of the proper galadh. This example
column3: could clarify the behavior of g in the two languages.
